snippet: Many in the United States who are believed to have Islamic State ties have never visited Syria, and thwarting them is like trying to prevent a school shooting.
abstract: American intelligence officials say investigating suspected Islamic State supporters in United States is more challenging if they have not attempted to travel to Middle East, which would make them more visible as potential jihadist recruits or trainees; ISIS has urged its American sympathizers to remain in US and wreak havoc, forcing authorities to anticipate less formal and less visible homegrown threats.

byline.original: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT, ERIC SCHMITT and MATT APUZZO

lead_paragraph: Many in the United States who are believed to have Islamic State ties have never visited Syria, and thwarting them is like trying to prevent a school shooting.

headline.main: U.S. Investigators Struggle to Track Homegrown ISIS Suspects
headline.print_headline: Suspects in U.S. Who Don’t Travel to Syria Are Even Harder to Investigate

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
